title: we wont forget barbara windsor
story: And “forgetting” has been very much on my mind this week, with the cruelty of dementia laid bare in Thursday night’s searing ITV documentary from the always- excellent Ross Kemp.He has a personal reason for highlighting the plight of ­sufferers and carers.His EastEnders screen “mum”, Barbara Windsor, was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s six years ago and her condition has rapidly deteriorated since lockdown.The -year-old film and TV legend is now so badly affected she may soon have to go into a care home. That is something her devoted husband, Scott Mitchell, has been dreading.The couple married in  with some cynics snfily declaring it would never last, mainly because of the -year age gap, but Scott proved them all completely wrong.He adores his we and has put his le on hold, and his physical and mental health at risk, to take care of his Barbara.Scott has also helped to raise funds and awareness for dementia charities, even taking part in the London Marathon with a group of Barbara’s friends from EastEnders.It has been deeply sad to see how this disease has ravaged one of the most delightful women in showbiz.I always adored interviewing Barbara. She was sunny, funny, full of fascinating stories and always interested in everyone and everything.She would have a laugh with the crew, a cheery chat with our production team and was exactly the same whether the cameras were rolling or not.I know a lot of famous actors and entertainers who are grumpy gits until the red light goes on. Barbara was never like that. She is a consummate professional, but also a delightfully warm human being.I remember seeing her at an event in London, where she was swamped by photographers and members of the public. She’s so tiny I couldn’t actually see her in that large sea of people, but what I did observe was how everyone came away with an autograph or a selfie.Barbara is old school. She always said she owes her fame to the public and that they deserved a smile, a cheery wave and a quick photograph.That’s why she is so adored and why we are so very upset she is having to go through this anguish. Scott says her speech is growing worse and she now struggles to find the words to express herself.She ends up sitting shaking her head in sadness and frustration. Barbara is also getting up two or three times a night, becoming unsteady on her feet and falling over. Scott is worried sick that she will suffer a really serious injury.Sometimes Barbara looks at old photos of herself and asks, “Who is she ” and increasingly she doesn’t recognise Scott, which cuts him to his very heart and soul.This disease is so brutal, because it chips away at the sufferer, steals their memories and erodes what makes them unique. You gradually lose the person you love and have to mourn them while they are still alive. That’s why the work both Scott and Barbara have been doing is so vital.When she bravely told us she was ill two years ago, the Alzheimer’s Society saw visits to its website double and one-off donations to the charity rose by  per cent.She made a plea to the PM to help carers and sufferers, and to increase funding, and Barbara was one of the few people that made Boris Johnson stop waffling and actually listen.Dementia is a second epidemic within this pandemic, which is why we need more documentaries like the ones from Ross.There are , sufferers that we know about in the UK, and with us all living longer that number will carry on increasing.Relatives caring for those blighted by the disease can often feel alone and helpless. GPs and the NHS do their best, but it can be a lottery as to what expert care is available.As we have seen during this crisis, care home workers are an extraordinary group of people who treat their frail and elderly patients like a second family, but no one really wants to put a beloved parent or partner into a nursing home.There comes a time, however, when there is no other choice. Scott is now facing that prospect and it is tearing him apart. I also spoke this week to the musician Naughty Boy, whose mum Zahida suffers from dementia.He is a devoted son and lives with his mum to take care of her. Naughty Boy is backing Dementia UK’s Lives On Hold campaign, which focuses on carers and how draining it is for them, especially since lockdown. He wants to stress that there is help out there. I was touched at how he makes sure there is at least one thing every day for his mum to look forward to, to give her joy.He tries to see some light in the darkness and it’s also something Scott has always tried to do. He has to be Barbara’s memory and keep a hold of the love they have for one another.Eventhey have to be parted so she can go into a home, nothing can take that love away from him or anyone  going through the same sad experience.IF you are going to quote Game Of Thrones, then for the love of God at least get it right.Tone deaf Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab dismissed those who support the Black Lives Matter campaign by taking a knee, as seeming to “get the idea from Game Of Thrones”.This was not only hugely insulting, but Raab didn’t even bother to get the phraseology right. In Game Of Thrones, the characters are willing to die before they would BEND the knee in front of despots and royalty.In the real world it’s about expressing solidarity against racial inequality.Raab believes the heartfelt gesture is a “symbol of subjugation and subordination” and he would only do so for the Queen and his we. Those who take the knee, including footballers at theof the Premier League this week, and many protesters here and in the US, were astounded by his crass remarks.Following such wide­spread incredulity and anger, Raab has been furiously back-tracking. I do hope his Twitter clarication is genuine and not just another Government damage-limitation tactic.If this really was an episode of Game Of Thrones, he would have had his a*** handed to him by my favourite character, Sandor Clegane, known as The Hound.After that encounter, I guarantee he would never again be able to bend any part of his anatomy.HOLLYOAKS actor Adam Rickitt is an astonishingly candid and brave man. He not only spoke about his mental health at a time when it was considered career-destroying, but has talked frankly this week about being infertile.Adam suffers from an auto-immune disease that has made it impossible for him to ever father children. The -year-old has ankylosing spondylitis, which has had a devastating effect on his sperm count.While other men might have felt embarrassed about it, Adam has been refreshingly honest. He revealed the doctor told him most men have three million sperm, but he only had two. Not two million but TWO.He and his we Katy Fawcett, a top correspondent with Good Morning Britain, are very happy with their three dogs. Adam has been equally upfront about his mental health and suicidal thoughts. Since meeting Katy in  his le has turned around and, alongside acting jobs, he’s running a craft beer bar and shop. The couple call it their “baby”.They adore each other and are lucky to feel complete without kids.GWYNETH PALTROW’S latest attention- seeking wheeze is to bring out a candle that “smells of her orgasm”. This is a follow-up to last year’s model that bore the catchy title, “This candle smells of my vagina”.Not sure about you, but I have no wish to have my living room reeking of Gywn or anything to do with her sex le.I also cannot begin to imagine the sheer buttock-clenching embarrassment suffered by her two teenage kids.I think what her candles really smell of are pure unadulterated bulls**t.THE Oscars and Baftas have been delayed for a few months due to Covid-, so this could be a good time for the film industry to have a rethink about the whole business of award shows.Instead of a seemingly never-ending run of ceremonies, perhaps there should be a cull. In the US they could keep the Oscars for films, the Emmys for TV and the Tonys for theatre, and here the Baftas, NTAs and Oliviers.Then each event would be special, rather than a seemingly endless parade of bored-looking stars like Renee Zellweger, above, done up to the nines and wishing they were at home.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: end virtue signalling serious conversation
story: Mirza, recently appointed to run the Government’s new Racial Inequality Review, has been described as a “racial gatekeeper”, among other things Patel has been accused of “gaslighting” by Labour MPs after talking about her own experiences of racism.I feel it especially because I have something in common with Patel and Mirza: We are ethnic minority women who do not accept the standard leftist view of racism.In  I spoke out about the state of our education system at the Conservative Party Conference, criticising the “culture of excuses”.For some, this was the worst thing I could do. No matter that I am not, nor have ever been, a member of the Conservative Party.I would never be forgiven by some people, who just couldn’t understand why an ethnic minority person would have sympathy for Conservative policies. At best we’ve been hoodwinked at worst we must just be plain evil.It often feels like we are not allowed to think for ourselves, outside of the orthodoxies set down by left-wing political groupthink.In the days of fighting to set up my school, and in our first few years of establishing ourselves, I received racist emails and threats of violence — from the Left.There were protests outside my school and abuse was shouted in my face from militant union members opposed to free schools.My detractors tried hard to discredit me in ways that made sense to them.There was even a running Wikipedia battle over my heritage, lasting for years.It was regularly edited to state that I was of Indian descent, while some people claimed my ancestry to be Indian Ugandan, and thereforethat I must hate black people.It was absurd, and I didn’t know from one day to the next what race my Wikipedia page would say I was.While it seems a bizarre thing to fight over, some opponents clearly believed that my criticisms of the education system and my support for free schools could be discountedI wasn’t black.My experience ten years ago is why today I have the greatest sympathy for Conservative MPs such as Priti Patel and Kemi Badenoch. Heaven knows what actual Tory MPs from ethnic minorities must have to endure.Mirza has been working with the Conservative Party for many years and her simple appointment to this role has enraged her detractors. For them, a “good” ethnic minority is one who always toes the leftist line.So play around with my Wikipedia page, make me Indian with a couple of keyboard strokes, and suddenly not only have they wiped my mother out of existence, but my words don’t really matter any more. This accusation of “not being black enough” raised its ugly head when Priti Patel was accused of distracting from the racism facing black people by highlighting her own experiences — assomehow her struggles were worth less because she is of Indian heritage .That being called a “P**i” as a young girl wouldn’t have had the same crushing, hurtful impact as any other racial slur. Similarly, Munira Mirza has been accused of not being able to understand the experiences of black people because she is of Pakistani origin.The recent protests inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement should have provoked serious conversations about the meaning and impact of race we all need to explore the nature of racism and what to do about it.But it is clear to me, from the black boxes on Instagram to the meaningless supportive BLM statements on corporate websites, that few people are interested in examining race in our own society.Most people want an easy fix, a stamp of approval that will allow them to be branded a non-racist so that they can go back to their normal lives, satisfied that they are a good person .This is not even remotely helpful to anyone, it’s simple box ticking but the desire to signal “anti-racism” instead of just not being a racist is so prevalent that at times I wonder whether human beings have the capacity to distinguish between the two: The signal and the reality.This tick-box race culture goes hand in hand with the oppression Olympics. Hierarchies of race are the easy bingo card that allows ethnic people to be ticked off on a sheet.Chinese  Sorry, only two oppression points for you. Black  Wow, that’s ten points! You go straight to the top!This is why,you are merely interested in appearing to be non-racist, rather than actually being a non-racist, you will buy into the idea of this totem pole of oppression.You will ignore that race and class are so much more complex than this.My father was of Indian heritage, but he came from a much poorer environment than my black mother and grew up without any shoes.Le is more complicated than the tick-box culture allows, butyour only interest in race is to do enough to signal to everyone that you aren’t a racist, then you will promote that hierarchy enthusiastically, because it is the perfect prop for your non-racist dissimulation. It doesn’t require any thought or effort.The reality of being anti-racist requires years of reading and discussion, befriending a iety of black people, including ones who think dferently from you politicallyand really coming to terms with one’s own uncomfortable feelings around race. Signalling requires a black box on Instagram and instantly everyone approves of you. You can see why most people choose the simpler option.In fact, spending a letime helping black boys realise their potential, something Black Lives Matter should approve of, instead of earning me adoration as a black box on Instagram does, has given me many enemies.My -plus years of improving young people’s lives is meaningless next to the superficial letters of support for BLM, because making a useful dference to people’s lives is less important than being seen to do so. It is a wonder why anyone ever does anything truly good at all.But there is one way of being anti-racist in a very simple and real way that takes no time at all.Allow Priti Patel, Kemi Badenoch and Munira Mirza the right that so many white people enjoy and take for granted: The right to think for themselves.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fitness blogger accuses marks spencer copying swimwear
story: Zanna van Dijk said the retail giant had “blatantly copied” her Stay Wild Swim designs, which are made from recycled ocean plastics.The London-based blogger, who has k Instagram followers, shared a selection of photos online comparing the two ranges.She said: “It’s ridiculous. I’m fuming. Shame on your Marks and Spencer.She added: “I’m in shock. It’s so upsetting because our brand is all about slow fashion, sustainability and ethics, and this is cheap fast fashion.“It just feels like the principles of our brand have been compromised.“For them to just blatantly copy our designs could detract from our sales and I just don’t think that is okay.“Even the colours are the same. They could at least have done it in bright yellow or something.”Zanna said she first noticed the MS cossies when a friend of her business partner spotted them in store.The MS range featured similar shapes, styles and colours to the Stay Wild Swim range. And Zanna believes it is the second time MS have copied her and business partner Natalie Glazes creations. The blogger said: “The reality is that about nine or  months ago MS released one design which was very similar to ours, practically identical.“But we didn’t react as it was only one design and we thought that maybe it was a coincidence.“Clearly because we didn’t react they just went in and copied the whole collection.”Zanna and Natalie have since taken to social media to share their outrage.Zanna said: “We have a  so it makes sense for us to try and use it.“We wanted to raise awareness of this issue because I’ve definitely seen it in the past when other small businesses have had larger corporations steal their designs and claimed them as their own.“I would hate for anybody  to experience this. We want to get some justice.Marks and Spencer have since responded, telling the Sun Online: “We’ve been selling our zipped swimsuits since . “We update our in-house designs frequently with dferent colours and styles, at the moment they’re the popular colour block design using the blue and orange from our Good Move activewear range. “There are signicant dferences between the swimsuits including the shape of the back.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: more mums cabinet ministers schools re opened
story: Out of the  ministers attending the key government meetings, just seven are women.There are fewer women in the most senior roles since the reshuffle in February and apparently none in the PM’s close circle.I don’t know the precise domestic circumstances of the men who form Johnson’s immediate circle but I’m pretty sure they are not the main ones overseeing the home schooling of their children, nor the daily task of making sure they are properly fed, clothed and entertained — all at the same time as holding down their job.And I just can’t help but think thatthe many women who are doing just that right now were also dealing with the logistics of how the heck to get schools open again — well, it would have happened by now.So many of my friends with school-aged children have commented that home- schooling seems to be being seen as “women’s work” even when both parents are working.In the same way that the task of raising money for the PTA and organising the school fair falls predominantly to women, now that there is a new school-related task for parents — the small matter of home-educating their children — guess who it’s mostly falling to You’ve guessed it. Mums.And when you are responsible for home-educating your children as well as working out how to feed them three meals a day while holding down your job and everything  you used to do before children went to school at home, there is a strong incentive to get those schools open. And quick.Perhaps less so when someone  is taking care of all that stuff for you.Getting our classrooms back up and running may well take a bit of lateral thought, because of course it has to be safe to do so. But on the basis we can now pop to Zara or Ikea, surely we can open our schools safely Few disagree that lockdown should have included schools, but they need to open as soon as it is safe to do so.Yes, these things all need proper managing and organising. So why don’t schools ask local business leaders to help them with the logistics and arrangements To socially distance safely, we may need to cut class sizes in half and have twice as many classrooms, so why not look to use dferent spaces, for example empty community halls, empty libraries, empty offices etc.What about outdoor learning in small groups If we cut classrooms by half we will need twice as many teachers.So how about encouraging unemployed graduates to work as teaching assistants Or asking retired teachers to come out of retirement, just as many nurses did at the beginning of the pandemic.You know you can find the solution when it’s your problem to solve. Which is why any government and any Cabinet should be as representational of “real le” as possible, which is why we need more women advising the Prime Minister.That said, no doubt many women just don’t fancy a le in politics. When you look at the abuse, death treats, and sexism they face, who can blame them.But unless there are people from all walks of le — including women — in the Cabinet, then the issues that affect real people will not be properly tackled or solved.Just look at the incredible effect that some of the world’s female leaders have had when they’ve acted swtly and decisively in the face of Covid-.Germany’s Angela Merkel has kept deaths in her country down to just  per million — compared to  per million in the UK.New Zealand’s inspiring Jacinda Ardern has overseen a remarkable response to the pandemic which involved a rapid, draconian lockdown.Only  people died there. She has been widely praised for her strength in leadership.These daily UK Government press briefings have made it all too clear that we are crying out for more women at the helm.The steady stream of menfielding questions on the topics of the day has been alarming. Priti Patel’s appearances could be counted on one hand.It does make you wonder whether we’d be in a healthier positionmore women had been given more prominence in Boris’s Cabinet.I think we would be.Until recently, many people knew Maya Jama as the girlfriend of rapper Stormzy, but they broke up as a couple last year.What people are now gradually realising is that she has had a fantastic career in her own right – and she proved it last week when she stole the show while co-presenting Peter Crouch: Save Our Summer on BBC.And it wasn’t because her low-cut top, inset, raised a few eyebrows, though certainly not mine.As she rightly pointed out, she can dress how she pleases.She stole the show because she is good at what she does and is engaging.At the age of  she has already done a stint on MTV, DJing on Rinse FM, a job on Radio , and now she is presenting Saturday night TV.Andit weren’t for Covid- she would be acting in her first film around about now too.Plus, as a sideline she is launching a skincare range and has a mysterious big project brewing – rumoured by some to be Strictly Come Dancing.In fact, she said in an interview this week that lockdown is the first time since she was  that she has had such an extended rest .All of this would be impressive for any -year-old but way more so when you know that Maya’s father was in and out of prison for much of her childhood. And not only that – in  when she was , her then boyfriend, Rico Gordon, was killed in a shooting.These are the kind of le experiences that can lead young people down a very dferent track to the one that Maya has put herself on, and for that alone she deserves our admiration.But really we should admire her solely because she is so good at what she does, and such a brave and eloquent voice for her generation.Kate Ferdinand has announced she is pregnant and expecting her first child with husband of nine months Rio.It really could not happen to a nicer or more deserving couple, as evidenced by the fact that when they told Rio’s three children – Lorenz, , Tate, , and nine-year-old Tia – the youngsters jumped up and down with joy.That is the reaction of children who have been made to feel happy, secure and, above all, loved by their father and his new we, despite having gone through the pain of losing their mother.Kate put the video on Instagram with the caption: “The crazy house is about to get a little bit crazier . . . every time I watch this it makes me cry, the best reaction. Baby Ferdy, we are all so excited to meet you.”Good luck to them.About bloody time.This is an opportunity to be seized.If we think carefully about how to spend the money in the right way, we can achieve a great deal of good in this country – and God knows we need that right now.I am sure I’m not the only one having mixed feelings about shops reopening and the huge step back towards “normality” that we all took this week.On the one hand it feels like a huge relief.Thank goodness things are moving again.On the other, I’m a bit worried about how to get out of my pyjamas, start wearing make-up and navigate my working wardrobe again.On balance, though, I’m excited for us to all start doing what we can to get the economy growing again.Talking of shops reopening, I didn’t enjoy the level of scorn being heaped by people on social media on to the huge queues outside Primark stores, which re-opened on Monday.I think before they are so judgmental they should stop for a minute and consider that many people do not have credit cards so cannot shop online.But not only that – say what you like about Primark clothes, one thing they are is cheap.Families with kids who have grown out of their gear over lockdown couldn’t wait to get in there to grab what they needed, and there was a distinctly snobbish element to some people’s judgment.They should think before they speak.Photos of Reese Witherspoon running in a baseball cap with her face concealed by a mask made me realise celebs everywhere – especially those with lockdown hair and faces that might need a bit of  TLC – are seeing this season’s new must-have accessory as an opportunity to conceal a multitude of sins.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: remember saying have best cops
story: Well, yes, sonny, it still applies to the mugs in the street but not to an anarchic mob that decides it wants to chuck a statue of a long-dead slave trader into the briny or go shopping at Primark.Pity the poor rank-and-file ­copper.Our police are forced to jump to the tune of painfully woke senior officers and witless politicians making it all up as they go along.One moment cops are shouting warnings at nubile sunbathers in bikinis about the dire threat they pose to the nation’s health and the next those same coppers are required to stand meekly by while a crowd attempts to desecrate Churchill’s statue, or face drunken far-right thugs chucking bottles in their faces.The frontline copper is just obeying orders, of course. They do what they are told to by top brass but these horribly mixed messages are not a good look.It was once commonplace to hear that this country has the best police force in the world. When was the last time you heard that But it was true. Think of the late PC Keith Palmer, who died in  while heroically preventing a kne-wielding Islamist terrorist from entering the Palace of ­Westminster.Yet during this lockdown, there has been a steady draining away of respect for the police.How we all chortled to learn that in Hampshire,  per cent of police are now overweight or obese — the fat-buttocked blue line.While in London, when a ­protester leapt in front of the PM’s car causing a minor crash, it was hardly a complete surprise to see day-dreaming officers gormlessly staring off into space, as oblivious as Keystone Cops in a coma.There is a growing lack of respect for the police and that is the reason why  officers were injured in one weekend.The ordinary copper has been poorly led, leading to inevitable inaction the moment they are met by protesters or a crowd of eager shoppers at Nike Town.Their own senior officers seem far more concerned about ­displaying their politically correct credentials rather than anything resembling law and order. More than  years ago, the Macpherson Report into the death of Stephen Lawrence in South East London found the Met Police to be ­“institutionally racist”.There has been a great overhaul in the force since.It is hugely welcome that there are Black Asian and Minority ­Ethnicofficers now in senior Scotland Yard roles. This was long overdue.But there is still a long way to go before the force can be regarded as being truly erse.Five of the nation’s police forces have only one black officer.Forces in Durham, North ­Yorkshire, Warwickshire, Dyfed-Powys and North Wales had only one black officer in their ranks each as of March last year.This doesn’t mean our officers should be drawn into events like the death of George Floyd , miles away.It should be self-evident that British police were not in any way responsible for that death in Minneapolis.And yet a statement issued on behalf of Britain’s Chief Constables solemnly stated: “We stand alongside all those across the globe who are appalled and ­horried by the way George Floyd lost his le.“Justice and accountability should follow. We will tackle bias, racism or discrimination wherever we find it.”But the appalling racist violence of American cops — or indeed, when the police go on a violent rampage in Paris or Hong Kong — should not be clumsily confused with the issues our bobbies face here.As the violent clashes of the past few weeks have demonstrated, our officers should be focused on our own problems dealing with crime on our own streets.PAMELA ANDERSON ­promotes fake leather vegan handbags.You would never guess it’s mostly plastic.The bag, I mean. Not Pam.“Is Dad a James Bond fan by any chance ” cooed Britt on the website Cameo. “I’m here to fulfil your wildest desires.”Wow – you’ve got one old dad going now, Britt!You couldn’t get me a signed photo of Ana de Armas, could you AND they’re off!” cried Lizzie Cundy. No, not her clothes – the horses.“Doing this year’s Ascot at home,” sighs Lizzie.Just as well. They would never have let her into the Royal Enclosure carrying that glass of champagne.SIR KEIR STARMER, Labour’s gutless leader, is scared ­witless of upsetting his union paymasters so he can’t bring himself to admit that opening our schools is safe – despite sending his own children to school throughout the lockdown.Same old Labour – always hypocrites when it comes to educating their children. One law for them etc.Meanwhile, the Government is finally showing some urgency about getting the schools open again for all, pumping £billion into state schools over the next year, including £million for the most disadvantaged children.It beggars belief that non-essential shops have reopened while schools remain closed or see only a trickle of pupils.There are no non-essential children.DOMINIC RAAB says he would only take the knee for his missus and the Queen.Cue widespread and totally predictable outrage from the likes of Labour’s permanently apoplectic David Lammy.But as Raab’s Jewish father Peter fled the Nazis as a six-year-old Czech in , I don’t think the Foreign Secretary needs lessons in opposing racism from anyone.And to many of us, “taking the knee” looks like a servile and empty gesture, bowing down before the great gods of woke.During World War Two, there were those who thought Dame Veras songs were too sentimental for fighting men who might never see home again.But with We’ll Meet Again and The White Clfs Of Dover, Vera gave hope in the darkness all around.It is signicant that the Queen chose that immortal phase “We will meet again” in her address to the nation at the height of the pandemic.Some songs last for ever.DAN WALKER, the BBC presenter, mocks a supporter of the online campaign Defund The BBC as “a Russian bot” – meaning a fake account run by foreign communists who seek our demise.Oh, Dan! Defund The BBC was started by a smart young Glasgow University student called James Yucel.And there are millions who believe that the funding model of the BBC is laughably old-fashioned in the age of Netflix, Amazon and the rest.Sometimes I think it is the BBC’s preachy, ridiculously overpaid presenters such as Gary Lineker, Emily Maitlis and deluded Dan Walker, above, who are the Russian bots – planted to hasten the end of the BBC.Great, but Lewis is paid £million a year by the Mercedes-AMG Petronas Formula One team – and , forced labourers once toiled in Mercedesfactories in Nazi Germany.I drive a BMW, who also used slaves under the Nazis.When it comes to symbols of racism, Lewis, German carmakers take some beating.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids are being recruited into county lines gangs through fortnite
story: They say criminals use apps and video games, popular with millions of teens, to snare children in their own homes.The warning comes amid growing concerns that youngsters are being increasingly used to courier drugs during the pandemic.Older dealers pay them to ferry cannabis, cocaine and other Class-A’s, because they are less likely to be stopped by cops.Reformed gang-member Matthew Norford, who runs community group  Message in Manchester, says dealers’ tactics have developed so they don’t even have to leave the house.He said: “Gangsters and drug dealers won’t stay in just because there’s a lockdown. Dealers are still speaking to kids, new clients and parents.“You’ve got dealers telling kids to go on Houseparty and Fortnite and ask othersthey want to make some money.“They’re getting youngsters to recruit their friends. Proper drug dealers can’t be bothered to make a fake online profile - they get the workers to do it for them.“These kids are already on Instagram and Snapchat and then they just pick someone. County lines is a pandemic in itself.”He said kids are also posing as take-away food riders to deliver drugs for county lines gangs during lockdown.He added: “They are hidden in takeaway boxes and plastic bags  in a bid to try and avoid detection by cops.“Many of those delivering the drugs are even using branded takeaway carriers and clothing to try and stay one step ahead of police.”The National Crime Agency confirmed they were aware of the trend - which has been dubbed “Deliveroo For Drugs”.A spokesman said: “Criminals will sometimes pose as key workers in case they are stopped and questioned by police.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sir keir starmer silence schools reopen
story: The Labour leader has sat on the fence while his party is ided over whether it is safe for kids toto classes.He has claimed that the longer schools are shut, the more damage that will be done to children.But he refuses to rein in is shadow education secretary who has “welcomed” news that schools won’t make a fulluntil after the summer.Leftie Rebecca Long-Bailey – an ally of ex-leader Jeremy Corbyn – also backs a militant teaching union which has urged members not to engage with heads about opening schools.Sir Keir was under mounting pressure to come off the fence after the Boris Johnson vowed to get all children back to full-time school in September.The PM believes this can be achieved by increasing from  to  the protective “bubbles” children are placed in.There is mounting evidence that the prolonged absence from school during the coronavirus pandemic is causing long-term harm to many children.Children’s Commissioner Anne Longfield has warned that poorer children risk falling further behind in their education.And she says is even more damaging for . million with a vulnerable family background.Last week , paediatricians wrote to the PM urging him to make the re-opening of schools a priority.Sir Keir has called on the government to secure a “national consensus” on the re-opening of schools to address “valid safety concerns” raised by unions.But he refused four times last week to say whether or not thought it was safe for children to be back in school.Tory MP Jonathan Gullis, a former teacher who sits on the Commons education committee, said: “Keir Starmer is developing a bit of a habit of staying silent. He’s become the quiet man of politics.“He remained silent during Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership when anti-semitism was re. He also sat on the fence when members of his front bench made disgusting comments about the Home Secretary Priti Patel.“It’s time we heard a bit more from the Labour leader. If he doesn’t like what the government is doing, he should lay out his position.“Perhaps it’s because on many of the key issues – including Brexit – he is out of touch with working people, particularly those in so-called Red Wall seats his party lost at the last election.”The “quiet man” jibe has echoes of Sir Iain Duncan Smith’s troubled two-year spell as Tory leader when he told critics: “Do not underestimate the determination of a quiet man.”Sir Keir, who was elected Labour leader in April, has confirmed his two children have been attending school throughout the pandemic.But his shadow chancellor Anneliese Dodds has said she does not have the evidence to convince her to send her own children to school.Tory MP Robert Halfon, who chairs the education select committee, said “This was a big test for Sir Keir to prove whether he is going to de-Corbynise the Labour party.“About four million children have not had any contact with their teachers since March. It’s time for Sir Keir to show some leadership and tell his MPs what he really thinks.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum glassing boyfriend earlobe pub
story: Sophie Ellis, , tried to headbutt Jamie Marshman before smashing a pint glass over his head while he stood at the crowded bar in the Saracens Head pub in The Tything, Worcester.The mother-of-one, of Slade Avenue, Warndon Villages, Worcester, was given a suspended sentence at Worcester Crown Court on Wednesday.CCTV footage of the attack was played in court which showed men trying to drag Ellis away from Mr Marshman after he was hit with the glass.She admitted Section  woundingbut denied the more serious charge of Section  woundingfollowing the attack on October  last year.Mr Marshman is in a relationship with the defendant and had not supported the prosecution.On occasions, he stood up in the public gallery and leaned on the railing overlooking the court.Antonie Muller, prosecuting, said the couple had a disagreement in the pub at around pm effectively about him not paying her enough attention.Later at the bar, she stuck him twice with the victims own half-full pint glass.Mr Muller said: She lost her self-control. She slapped him in the face and tried to headbutt him.The glass broke on his head. He was left with ious cuts to his head including a partially severed earlobe.The victim received four stitches in his ear at the hospital while Ellis made full admissions in the police interview.She said she was ashamed of what she had done, Mr Muller told the court.Ellis had no previous convictions before the assault and had shown remorse, the court was told.Jason Patel, defending, asked his client to be given full credit for her early guilty plea.He said the CCTV footage showed it was not one way, describing her as mortied by her actions.James Burbidge QC, the Recorder of Worcester, said that Ellis claimed Mr Marshman was a coercive and controlling inidual but added: This is not a court of moral judgement.He discounted  per cent from theof the custodial element of her sentence to reflect her early guilty plea.Mr Marshman had also entered a retraction statement on March .Judge Burbidge said that Mr Marshman was not the only victim - its not a crime that only affects him and that the case could not be decided by the parties involved.He added: In his statement, he sounds indignant.The judge read out part of a letter from Mr Marshman, who said police and the Crown Prosecution Service had not taken the time or effort to see or consider a bigger picture, He branded their actions despicable before going on to say he intends to make a complaint.However, the judge also read out Mr Marshmans original witness statement in which the victim said: There was no reason for Sophie to glass me.Im in full support of police action for this relationship is now over. I do not wish for Sophie to contact me any longer. I always thought she had a psycho streak.Mr Marshman, who said he had drunk  pints of beer, initially described what happened to him as completely uncalled for.Judge Burbidge sentenced Ellis to  months in prison suspended for one year and ordered her to complete  hours of unpaid work.He told her she must organise childcare to allow her to complete it but would not be able to do the unpaid work immediately due to the coronavirus pandemic.The judge also ordered her to complete  rehabilitation activity requirement days.The defendant could be seen crying and dabbing her eyes with a tissue before she walked free from court.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russian nurse see through coronavirus gown modelling contract nadia zhukova
story: Nadia Zhukova, , was seen wearing only lingerie under her transparent PPE as she gave patients on a male ward their medicine.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesShe was originally rapped by hospital bosses “non-compliance with the requirements for medical clothing”.The nurse complained she was “too hot” in the hazmat gown - and her punishment was withdrawn after a furious backlash from the public against her being disciplined.Now she is not only keeping her job but posing as a model for a Russian sports clothes line while also announcing that she plans to study to become a doctor.Pictures show her wearing ZASPORT sport clothes, a brand founded by the daughter of a top FSB security service official.In her first detailed interview on last month’s lingerie scandal in her hospital in Tula, Nadia confessed she was still embarrassed to talk about it”.She told the brand’s website: “I understand what day this photo was taken, but how this spread so quickly over the Internet is still a mystery to me.“I remember that I ed from my sht, andalready sharing with me the link to the story.”The revealing pictures had been taken by one of her male patients.“Of course, I recognised myself and immediately closed my social network accounts …. I was not ready for such attention,” said Nadia.Going viral around the world was “just awful” but she praised her medical colleagues for their support, and the initial disciplinary move against her was reversed as support flooded in.Vladimir Putin’s former bodyguard Alexey Dyumin, , now governor of Tula region, strongly backed her.What helped me at that moment  My job.“I continued to go on my shts, and it is very pleasant that my colleagues and the whole team supported me.“They encouraged me: ‘Don’t worry! Youre a beautul one!’The chief doctor of our hospital , and even the governor of the Tula region , also spoke in my defence - thank you very much…“Doctors from other cities set up flash mobs to support me.“They understood that nobody knows how hot it is to work in a protective suit in summer.“It is asyou spend several hours in a sauna.“It even becomes hard to breathe and walk.”Her photoshoot came ahead of Russia’s Medic Day, which will be marked on Sunday, the professional holiday for doctors and nurses.Founder of the clothes brand Anastasia Zadorina, , called Nadia “one of the symbols of the coronavirus era.“This is a young, beautul and very brave girl, who makes her big contribution to the fight against Covid.”Zadorina, , is daughter of FSB colonel-general Mikhail Shekin, and her brand has a track record of promoting clothing adorned with patriotic and anti-Western slogans alluding to Russian missiles such as “Topol is not afraid of sanctions” and “Sanctions  Don’t tell my Iskanders”.But despite her new fame and role as a model, Nadia is determined study to become a doctor.“My goal is to go to medical university,” she said.“I will apply this summer…“The main thing for me is to become a good doctor and help people.I really want to tell everyone: do not relax .“Wear masks, use disinfectants.“Andyou feel signs of illness, don’t delay, consult a doctor.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keir starmer labour party silences women lisa nandy
story: Lisa Nandy launched a blistering attack on the party - as a -page dossier warned that another  seats could be lost on top of Boris Johnson’s -seat majority.The attack was made by the Shadow Foreign Secretary at an event last month just weeks into the reign of the new leadership.She said: “Too often the experience of women in the Labour Party in the north of England is that they get a position and they go onto the council and then their voices are silenced.”She continued: “I am sick of sitting on , Labour , with more people called John than there are women.”The revelation comes after the dossier on the disastrous election revealed it was the result of support fracturing over the past two decades.Nandy also claimed the party is being run by a small cabal of mostly males from the capital who foist their policies on their constituents.It could be seen as hitting out at Sir Keir Starmer whose constituency is in the heart of the city.She said: “We’ve got to be present in our communities and we have shrunk as a movement, into a small handful of people, largely men, dare I say it, in London, central London.“Not even most of London, but central London, who commission focus groups and polling, who go out and sell a message to the rest of the country.“We don’t listen to people where we are in power, we don’t listen to our candidates in other parts of the country.“When we talk about devolution, nobody believes us because they can see we haven’t done that ourselves as a Labour movement.”Nandy was one of five candidates who put herself forward to lead the party following Jeremy Corbyn’s decision to stand down after December’s election.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: quarter adults struggle decent meal coronavirus
story: ONE in four adults have struggled to put a decent meal on the table during the pandemic, a poll has revealed.Millions have tried to cope by buying cheaper food or eating less themselves so they can feed their children.But it has left many of them at risk of hunger and potential malnutrition, according to a survey of British households.Researchers were astonished by how many tried to cope by borrowing from neighbours, using foodbanks, sending their kids to eat where or restricting the foot they eat themselves.Nearly a third of those facing food insecurity say they had resorted to those drastic measures during the -week lockdown.The battle many face to access affordable food is laid bare in a survey of more than , people carried out last week by pollsters Prolic.Andrew Forsey, director of Feeding Britain, whose charity delivered a million meals this month, said it was not just the poorest households who had dficulty paying the bills and feeding their family.He said: “This survey shows the s to which millions of people in our country are going to keep themselves and their families fed during the pandemic.“It also reveals the uphill struggle that all too many of them have faced in doing so while attempting to maintain their dignity, independence, and self-sufficiency.“Many of our fellow citizens are now in that group. They have been exposed to hunger and potential malnutrition by a combination of low income and isolation, which has tended to follow a loss of earnings or problems with the benefits system.”Professor Greta Defeyter, of Northumbria University’s Healthy Living Lab, added: “These findings present an appalling picture of the high percentage of adults experiencing food insecurity in the UK.“If we, as a country, are to stand a chance of getting to grips with this problem, we need the Prime Minister to oversee and implement with urgency a national food strategy which enhances the supply, affordability, and accessibility of nutritious food to everyone in our country, while minimising the need to deploy the many coping strategies, such as the use of food banks, which we have identied through this survey.“These are often measures of last resort and do not compensate for an adequate income and the availability of affordable nutritious food within all communities.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc free tv licences over 75s october
story: The corporation has already put plans to force more people to pay the£. fee on ice until August due to the coronavirus pandemic.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut now it could be extended until October, the Sunday Times reported.The move is set to be discussed at a board meeting next month, it said.But senior BBC figures have allegedly signalled they want to delay the unpopular change again.A Whitehall insider said: “They’ve said August, but we’ve been told from the top of the BBC that they’re going to extend that to October.They say they won’t go any later than that — that’s the crux point and the government won’t intervene on that. title: dr rosena allin khan government
story: NewsopinionDr Rosena Allin-Khan: Government too slow on PPE, lockdown and testing but solidarity is keyBoris Johnsons Tories were too slow on three fronts as the coronavirus crisis took hold and we must now be prepared for a surge in demand for other health servicesShareCommentsByDr Rosena Allin-Khan:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsopinionThis week, footballer Marcus Rashford showed us all the power of having our voices heard" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn the last few months people across the country have dealt with situations that would have been unimaginable before. Families have lost loved ones. Our most vulnerable have been isolated for  weeks. Some have lost livelihoods. For NHS and care staff, the level of death, and the heart-breaking ­conversations that go along with it, have been on a magnitude never seen. Breaking the worst news imaginable to a loved one over the phone, simply makes the trauma worse. This virus has taken the humanity out of grieving. The country has looked for ­leadership throughout this crisis. While other countries were flattening the curve after taking crucial measures, the death rate in the UK continued to rise. The Government was too slow to get much needed protective equipment to frontline NHS and care staff. It was too slow to implement lockdown. And it was too slow to roll out mass testing. As the crisis starts to ease, we must be prepared for a surge in demand for other services. People have not had routine access to GPs. Many ­non-urgent hospital procedures have been ­postponed. As our country gradually reopens to the new normal, demand for these services will increase and it will require detailed planning.  People’s mental health and well-being are more important than ever. With record job losses and an all-time high in applications for universal credit, financial worries are greater. Families have lost loved ones without holding their hands in their final days and hours. It is simply heart-breaking how many people have not been able to say goodbye.  There has been hope in this crisis, however. Our communities have come together to ensure that our most ­vulnerable are not left alone. Food and supplies have been donated to make sure our frontline NHS staff have everything they need. Heroes such as Captain Tom Moore, have raised millions for NHS charities and other fantastic causes.  Communities have stepped up – it is time that the Government does too. It needs to have a plan in place for what support the NHS needs, whether there’s a second wave or not. Our mental health services need to be ready for the surge in demand. The Government has had months to make plans but we’ve heard nothing. Boris Johnson may try to distract people by grand promises, but until they are delivered we must not stop asking. We must not stop making noise.

title: free tv licenses over 75s
story: NewsFree TV licenses for over-s could be extended until OctoberThe £.-a-year leline was due to be means-tested from June , but BBC bosses delayed curbs for two months until August  because of the coronavirus pandemicShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsThe Mirror has been campaigning for the government to u-turn and protect the leline for so many older people" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFree TV licences for the over-s could be granted a further stay of execution, it has been claimed. The £.-a-year leline was due to be means-tested from June , but BBC bosses delayed curbs for two months until August  because of the coronavirus pandemic. Corporation chiefs could now extend the benefit until October, it was reported. A Whitehall source told the Sunday Times: “Theyaposve said August, but weaposve been told from the top of the BBC that theyaposre going to extend that to October. “They say they wonapost go any later than that — thataposs the crux point and the Government wonapost intervene on that. “It also wonapost bail them out. Some . million OAPs are due to lose free licences, with only over-s on Pension Credit being eligible when curbs come into force. The Conservatives pledged at the  election to protect free licences for the rest of that Parliament, which was due to run until . But the BBC had already been handed responsibility for funding the leline from June , under a deal agreed in . It says keeping licences free for all over-s would cost £million by -. The Mirror is campaigning to permanently save the benefit, with more than , readers backing the fight by completing coupons in the paper. Age UK Charity Director Caroline Abrahams said: “It’s very hard to see how the BBC could go ahead with their replacement for the over- free TV licence in August, as they currently plan. “Delaying the replacement scheme to October would be a sensible decision by the BBC in light of the pandemic – a terrible time for many older people during which, for many, their TV has never been more of a leline. “Of course, Age UK is convinced that free TV licences should stay in place permanently and we hope that the searing experience of the pandemic will persuade the BBC and the Government to look at the issue afresh and agree to keep them. “It would be a very popular decision.” Silver Voices director Dennis Reed said: It is no surprise to us that there is strong speculation that there may be a further delay in the scrapping of free licences for the over s. “Talks started on Friday between Silver Voices and the BBC to explore ways of settling this dispute once and for all, and the talks will continue next week.  “However, we will not be content with yet another short delay, without any indication that the Government and BBC are serious about dropping this cruel policy. “We cannot go on with the threat of the licence fee hanging over the heads of older people indefinitely. “The Government must be reminded of the impact of this policy on the lives of millions of older people.” Labour peer Lord George Foulkes, chairman of Parliamentaposs cross-party group for Ageing and Older People, said: “The current uncertainty is detrimental to many older people and proposals to withdraw free TV licences need to be scrapped permanently. “With that, the Government should cover the cost as a social benefit and not burden the BBC, which is already strapped for cash.” One expert believed the incoming director-general, Tim Davie, could save free licences permanently. Claire Enders, founder of media research company Enders Analysis, said: It would look good for the new DG to review the decision and protect the over-s.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe social distancing rule may be halved to one metre this week in an effort to kick-start the economy.The move is part of Boris Johnson ’s plan to end the “big national lockdown” with a raft of measures to reopen the country over the next two weeks.Lockdown has left the UK £trillion in debt, with the country now owing more than it produces in wealth.Chancellor Rishi Sunak said reducing distancing to m would “make an enormous dference” to businesses.PM Mr Johnson has been under huge pressure from industry and his own Chancellor to loosen the economic vice. With the public mood turning away from lockdown, pubs were preparing to open early in July whatever No’s advice. The Covid- alert has gone from four to three, meaning transmission is no longer “high” but it is in “general circulation”. The World Health Organisation recommends at least m distancing and France, China, Denmark, and Singapore, Canada and Spain are also reviewing their m rule. Here, we look at the impact of a m rule. Pubs - easier to get a pint Britons have jumped the gun on lockdown easing and are enjoying drinks in beer gardens and outdoor seat areas. These young drinkers were pictured yesterday in King’s Cross in London. Pubs are desperate for rules to be relaxed to save many of the . million hospitality jobs under threat. Landlords have warned that m distancing between customers will make trading “unsustainable”. Easing the rule will mean more clientele, saving some of the , pubs under threat of never reopening. Table service, strict cleaning rotas and floor markings will be the norm. Beer gardens in the first pubs to open will be patrolled to enforce new rules from July . Restaurants - get more diners in  Bosses have pleaded for an end to the m rule so that they can get enough diners in to make some money. Cutlery will be brought out with food, menus will be disposable and waiters must wash their hands between every serving – or wear gloves. Plastic screens may be used and diner arrival times will be staggered. Schools - ready for full classes  A cut to m means schools can open with full classes of around  when the academic year starts in September. Boris Johnson said he was “sure” relaxing the distancing rule, with other health safeguards, would allow all schools to reopen that month. Classes will increase from  to normal as the size of teaching “bubbles” double. A change would also enable pupils to take up more quickly the benefits of the Government’s £ billion catch up on learning fund.couldn’t meet the m rule. Hand sanitiser will be used at the door. Nightclub openings could be put back as dancefloors pose a risk. Shops - increase the footfall  Relaxing the rule will be a leline for larger shops and chains, allowing up to double the footfall. Smaller shops will find it harder, but the change will give many outlets a better chance of survival as stores struggle to recoup losses of £.million a week in lockdown. Hairdressers are expected to reopen from July , with advice to avoid face-to-face chat and talk only about essentials, facing the mirror. Around , people work in hairdressing and beauty. Sports - fans in the stadium  Fans will benefit from a m distancing, with the possibility of limited access to fixtures such as big football games. Some sports, such as cricket, not cleared under the m rule, will resume as players can play closer to each other. Golfers - who were allowed back last month - may also have more rules relaxed. More than , gyms will be among the last businesses to reopen. Travel - more holidays for all

title: mark steel hungry schoolkids should
story: NewsopinionMark Steel: Hungry schoolkids should obviously pay for the virus-led economic slumpI’m sick of hungry schoolkids who are so rich they keep their school dinner in an offshore account in the Cayman IslandsShareCommentsByMark Steel:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsopinionMarcus Rashford called on the Government to extend free school meals to summer holidays " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis government promised to be ambitious, and it hasn’t let us down. Like a dedicated athlete, it strives every week to break new records. A month ago it was planning to increase the surcharge foreign nurses pay to use the NHS, just as the whole country was banging saucepans for nurses, and a foreign nurse saved the le of the Prime Minister. Surely, we thought, this is the most idiotic extraordinarily dingbat psycho policy any government has thought of. But they’d hardly started. This week the Tories insisted there was no problem with the poorest kids going hungry over the summer, until forced to change their mind because of a campaign started by Marcus Rashford. If Dame Vera Lynn hadn’t died, next week they’d have announced they were cutting off her old-age pension until a petition started by Harry Kane attracted  million signatures and they had to back down. Then they’d reveal a scheme that all single mothers’ breast milk should be confiscated by officials from the Department of Works and Pensions, and sold to China as part of a post-Brexit trade deal. Finally they’d announce another U-turn after Sam Allardyce launched his opposition during post-match comments after the game between Southampton and Burnley. To start with, they tried to defend not feeding children over the summer. Because hungry schoolkids are obviously the people who should pay for the virus-led economic slump.  After all, they’re the people with all the spare money. I’m sick of hungry schoolkids who are so rich they keep their school dinner in an offshore account in the Cayman Islands. There are even specialist accountants, who advise their clients that “ you deposit a shepherd’s pie and two bowls of rhubarb and custard into our scheme in Jersey, it will be worth a wheelbarrow full of spaghetti bolognese by the end of the tax year”. Then they backed down, and praised Marcus Rashford for pointing out thatyou don’t provide dinners for people who haven’t got a dinner, they won’t have a dinner.  This must have been the problem all through the years of austerity. The Government would cut social services and libraries, but they couldn’t know this would result in social services and libraries being cut. If only a -year-old Marcus Rashford had written a letter explaining this, it might have been sorted out. But no, he was too busy practising how to beat a goalkeeper at the near post. It’s just “me, me, me” with some people.

title: revolutionary plan see workers paid
story: NewsRevolutionary plan will see workers paid wages the same day they earn themEXCLUSIVE: Rishi Sunak set to look at new way of paying employees would improve cash flow and stop reliance on payday lenders in times of crisisShareCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  JUN NewsChancellor Rishi Sunak could revolutionise how British workers are paid " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailChancellor Rishi Sunak is set to look at a plan which could let struggling workers draw pay as soon as they’ve earned it. The scheme would end the wait for a monthly wage and ease cashflow problems hitting millons during the Covid- pandemic. The proposal by ex-Labour Treasury minister Phil Woolas would mean you could use an employer’s payroll like a current bank account – instant access to your money but without any overdraft facility. Financial Secretary Jesse Norman now has the scheme in his in-tray. The Bank of England is interested in it and it’s backed by payroll providers covering . million employees. It will also be considered by the powerful Commons Treasury Select Committee looking for ways to help cash-strapped workers. Most companies pay monthly as it is more convenient to administer. But payroll advance technology means more frequent payments would cost just £ a month, most likely charged to the employee. Mr Woolas said: “Workers would rather have their money sooner, especially those struggling. The reality is most would opt to be paid weekly.  It could make the dference between keeping their heads above water and le on benefits.” Most common reasons for workers needing instant cash are unexpected household and car repairs or travel to help sick relatives. The scheme would end the need to turn to unscrupulous payday lenders. Half of UK workers do not have access to more than £ in cash.  Mr Woolas added: “This would put the legalised loan sharks out of business.” Mr Woolas has hooked up with financing techniques entrepreneur David Brown as part of a wider job protection scheme known as Toupay – an alternative to Mr Sunak’s taxpayer funded furlough safety net.

According to the paper, the tourism industry will be issued with new guidance on how to welcome guests back safely by the end of next week.It comes amid widespread expectation that Mr Johnson will announce that the two-metre rule will be cut to one next week, after the UKaposs coronavirus alert level was reduced for the first time since the start of the pandemic.The measure will pave the way for the PM to signicantly relax lockdown measures and restart the economy over the coming fortnight. It is understood that scientists have given their approval to reduce the distance people need to stay apart to one metre, provided other precautions are taken. MPs and tourism bosses have been calling for clarity over when bookings can be accepted again, and how the hospitality sector will operate post-lockdown. Former Environment Minister Owen Paterson told the Mail: To have any hope of saving this summer season for our tourist industry, the Government must announce this week what the arrangements will be for reopening on July . Ministers canapost leave our holiday parks, hotels and pubs in the dark any longer.  Meanwhile Patricia Yates, the chief executive of Visit Britain, said: We need to know what the plan is. The lack of Government guidelines and that uncertainty around the date is causing a great deal of consternation within the industry. The body estimates that the tourism sector, which accounts for three million jobs, will be hit with losses of up to £ billion this year because of coronavirus.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBeing a nurse is a vocation. They don’t go into the job for money or easy hours – they work long days saving lives and when they lose a patient, it’s upsetting. Paediatric nurse Genene Jones would often have an extreme reaction when a child on her ward died.Once, Jones even pulled up a stool in the cubicle where a young infant had passed away, just so she could stare at the body, seemingly processing the tragedy. No one liked to lose a patient, but for Jones it was a regular occurrence as she chose to work with the very sickest of children.After marrying her childhood sweetheart and trying her hand at being a beautician, Jones changed tack and trained to be a nurse. She ended up being a licensed vocational nursein the s at the former Bexar County Hospital in San Antonio, Texas, now the University Hospital of San Antonio. It was tough working in the intensive care unit, surrounded by so many poorly children, but Jones, then , took it in her stride, with her brisk and matter-of-fact demeanour. She had two children of her own, but they were mainly cared for by her adoptive mum. Jones was focused on her patients. But while many showered Jones with praise, staff did notice that babies and young children were dying at an alarming rate at the hospital. There was a high level of cardiac arrests and uncontrollable bleeding – symptoms unrelated to the diagnosis of the patients. When the numbers got into double figures, there was a  put together to launch an internal inquiry.It was discovered that around  babies had died from cardiac arrest or bleeding, during the period of May to December . It was clear something was very wrong. All the staff were interviewed and one of Jones’s colleagues even blatantly accused her of having a part in the deaths of the children. It was a shocking accusation, against a well-regarded nurse, but no one could prove anything.So, in the end, the hospital decided not to staff the intensive care unit with LVNs any more, Jones left and the matter was swept away. It should have been investigated further. Was there more to the accusation against Jones than first thought  Had the hospital been at fault and Jones had taken the fall  Whatever was believed at the time, it certainly didn’t stop her getting another job.  Jones went on to secure a position working with a Dr Kathleen Holland at her small Kerrville paediatric clinic in Texas. Shortly after starting, a number of children began experiencing breathing problems and had to be rushed to a nearby hospital. It was strange for children to fall ill while visiting the clinic. Then -month-old Cha McClellan was given what should have been a routine immunisation for mumps and measles. Jones administered the injection and, almost immediately, Cha had a seizure. Little Cha was rushed to hospital in San Antonio but on the way, she suffered a cardiac arrest and died. The abnormal cases were starting to attract attention. Dr Holland became suspicious and tests revealed a powerful muscle relaxant called succinylcholine in Cha’s body.Dr Holland found a bottle of it in her clinic with needle puncture marks in the lid as though some had been used – despite no record of it being needed or authorised. It turned out the bottle was partly filled with saline in an attempt to cover up that some of the succinylcholine had been used. Only Dr Holland and Jones had access to the drug and she informed the authorities and dismissed the nurse.  By now, the investigation had gathered pace. Jones had been linked to a number of other deaths – up to , including at the hospital where she’d worked previously. It was a chilling discovery and seemed unthinkable. Would a devoted nurse really be killing babies  Meanwhile, Jones’s first marriage had failed and she was married to a -year-old nursing assistant. He filed for orce shortly after Jones was charged with the murder of Cha and poisoning of a second child. Investigators had connected Jones to countless deaths and they weren’t even sure how to start piecing it all together.The evidence suggested she had been injecting babies and infants with a deadly dose of drugs to trigger heart failure and haemorrhaging – some patients she managed to save, while others died. But why  By the trial in  for Cha’s murder the media were obsessed with the killer nurse – the ‘Angel Of Death’.Prosecutors speculated that Jones, then , had injected children with drugs to demonstrate the need for a paediatric intensive care unit at the nearby hospital. Other prosecutors said Jones was taking her victims to the brink of death so that she could take action and save them – looking like a heroic miracle worker. She was found guilty and sentenced to  years. Later that year, Jones went to trial again for the poisoning of four-week-old Rolando Santos in January . Lawyers said she had injected Rolando with the blood-thinning drug Heparin. Thankfully this time, her victim survived. Again, Jones was found guilty and sentenced to  years in prison.  Once Jones was found guilty, Bexar County Hospital feared further litigation attempts and destroyed countless records that may have connected her to more deaths. To avoid costly payments and further embarrassment, the true number of her unfortunate victims will never be known. Even with the sentence given to Jones, the families still didn’t have closure. Because of a law in place at the time of her conviction that was designed to deal with prison overcrowding, she was facing only serving one third of her sentence and would get automatic parole in . Over the years she has been denied early parole on multiple occasions. But the loophole meant that the day would come when Jones would walk free. Jones would go on to inspire films, TV movies and crime programmes.She was even rumoured to be the inspiration for the character of Annie Wilkes from Stephen King’s Misery.  But for the families of the victims, her actions were painfully real. In , many knew that Jones was due for release and were determined that wouldn’t happen. Prosecutors filed five new murder charges against her that were linked to the deaths of babies in her care while she worked at what was then called the Bexar County Hospital. The charges related to the killing of Richard ‘Ricky’ Nelson, Rosemary Vega, Paul Villarreal and Joshua Sawyer, all in  and Patrick Zavala in .All were patients at the hospital and ranged in age from three months to two years. Court records indicate all the children were injected with an overdose of either muscle relaxers or pain killers. In January this year, Jones, now , made a plea deal. She pleaded guilty to the death of -month-old Joshua Sawyer. The charges relating to the other deaths were dropped.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn eerie abandoned farmhouse left frozen in time provided one photographer with a fascinating look into rural le more than  years ago. The home in County Tyrone, Northern Ireland, looks ordinary from the outside, but inside it is packed with newspapers dating back to , stopped clocks, a half-smoked pipe, and the owneraposs shoes left by the bed years after the property was vacated. Photographer Rebecca was invited in to see the decaying cottage after its owner died and she was left in awe of the haunting scenes within the perfectly preserved home. The cottage was lived in until  by the last of three brothers, who kept all of their family history, alongside tins of food from the early th century left unopened on the kitchen shelves.A man only identied as Dessie was the last to live there, leading aposa solitary le among the relics of the pastapos before moving into a home in  and passing away two years later. Rebecca, who owns the Abandoned NI website sharing photos of the derelict houses she explores, was allowed in by the owner to get a record of the incredible space before it was knocked down to make way for a new build. She said she was left gobsmacked by what she found, with old books, magazines, papers and photographs littered around the farm workeraposs cottage and left untouched. A clock on the mantel piece is stuck showing ., a pair of glasses are left ready to pick up and a rusted OXO tin has been left open, with two pocket watches stored inside. Hundreds of handwritten letters fill the drawers, and three kettles are sat on the stove, next to a cup which appears to have been placed there just before it was abandoned. Old books and newspapers including the Mid Ulster Mail from  were left sitting in the living room which had been shut off for more than  years, alongside one newspaper which reported the aftermath of the sinking of the Titanic in . Upstairs there remained rotting bedclothes, a bed pan on the floor and a flat cap left hanging on the end of a bedframe. Rebecca said she initially wasnapost surethe interior would be very interesting, but she has now created an exhibition based on the lives of Dessie and his family.  She said: I have to admit I saw the outside and wasnapost sureit was worth it. As soon as I opened the door I was blown away. I went into what I thought was a wee cottage and itaposs basically a social history museum. The cottage first appeared on maps in  and Rebecca began researching the family to help piece together the puzzle in all of the photographs. After talking to people to find out more about Dessie, she said: Among many things he was a fabulous cook, many friends still talk about his famous soda bread which he cooked over the original stove. Three people were killed when a man armed with a kne started stabbing people aposrandomlyapos at Forbury Park in the city. The incident was initially reported as being treated as a potential terror attack by security services, but police have since said it is not being treated as a terrorism incident, with a -year-old man arrested on suspicion of murder. A source told the Sunday Mirror: “A man pulled a kne and started attacking people at random in Reading, near the Crown Court. “It is thought there was one attacker who has surrendered to police.  It appears the attack was stopped when a lone sergeant, who responded when the alarm was raised, ran to the scene, saw the attacker running away with a kne and rugby tackled him to the ground.” Personal trainer Lawrence Wort, , who said he was around  metres from the attack, told PA: The park was pretty full, a lot of people sat around drinking with friends, when one lone person walked through, suddenly shouted some unintelligible words and went around a large group of around , trying to stab them. Another witness, Dan, , said he saw a man running around a circle of people apostappingapos them and at first thought they were playing a game - before he saw blood. Dan, a local, described how he and his friends had chosen a spot to sit and enjoy the sunshine at the park in Reading, Berkshire when he noticed the commotion. He said he saw a man approach a group sitting in the sun about  metres away.They were just in a circle chatting. Dan saw the man drew his attention because he appeared to be racing around the group tapping them on the head. He pointed them out to his friends. He told the : I thought they were playing duck duck goose and thought someone had been sick, we realised it was blood spraying out.  To their horror Dan and his friends suddenly realised the group were being attacked.
